On 11 January 2011, [[Sony Computer Entertainment]] (SCE) filed suit against [[George Hotz]] for publishing a technique for [[George Hotz#Hacking the PlayStation 3|hacking the PlayStation 3]] to allow it to run alternative [[operating system]]s like [[Linux]]. The case, [[Sony Computer Entertainment America v. George Hotz]], attracted much negative publicity among [[Hacker (term)|hacker]]s and on the Internet at large. On or about 4 April 2011, adherents of the [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]] movement declared in an open letter<ref>[http://anonnews.org/?p=press&a=item&i=787]</ref> that they were directing their hostile "undivided attention" against Sony, largely in response to the Hotz case.<ref>Brown, Mark. (2011-01-28) [http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2011-04/4/anonymous-targets-sony Anonymous hacktivists turn attention towards Sony (Wired UK)]. Wired.co.uk. Retrieved on 7 July 2011.</ref>
On 21 April 2011, Sony Computer Entertainment was subjected to [[Denial-of-service attack|distributed denial of service attack]]s, apparently in retaliation for its case against Hotz.<ref>http://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/04/21/psn_outage_ddos_rumours/</ref><ref>[http://www.dailytech.com/Anonymous+Engages+in+Sony+DDoS+Attacks+Over+GeoHot+PS3+Lawsuit/article21282.htm Anonymous Engages in Sony DDoS Attacks Over GeoHot PS3 Lawsuit]. DailyTech. Retrieved on 7 July 2011.</ref> On April 26 Sony announced that the [[PlayStation Network]] (PSN) had been attacked, allegedly resulting in the theft of the personal information of 77 million account holders. Gizmag.com.
